hey,
 
Yes, I've seen your robot dual domain. In fact it was that experiment that got me into NEAT instead of just regular neural networks. I'll look into trying something small first and thanks for the encouragement. I'll be sure to keep the yahoogroup posted on anything that I do. Take care
 
timmy

Kenneth Stanley <kstanley@...> wrote:
Timmy,

First, I think you're in the right group to talk about this so I
wouldn't worry about that.  

What you're saying sounds doable but definitely you will have to learn
a lot to set something like that up.  What I would suggest is slowly
scaling up to your goal.  First, just learn how to use NEAT by
downloading a version you like and playing with it.  Then maybe try
altering an expriment to see how things change.  Then you can think
about designing your own experiment.  You may want to start with a
really simple one, such as one wolf and one rabbit, and move up in
complexity.  Have you seen my robot duel experiments?  They are
somewhat related to the kind of thing you are talking about (i.e.
predator/prey/food situations):

http://nn.cs.utexas.edu/pages/research/neatdemo.html

Anyway, what I would suggest is getting started just by using NEAT and
seeing what problems come up.  That will help you discover the
specific questions you will need answered to accomplish your goal,
which you can then ask the group.

ken

--- In neat@yahoogroups.com, "t_bommel" <t_bommel@y...> wrote:
> Hi,
> 
> I'm new to neural networks, NEAT, and even computer science (only 
> matlab experience). Anyway, I want to make a biological system of 
> wolves and rabbits and I thought it'd be cool if each agent had 
> a "brain" to guide its movement and if their brain evolved with
time. 
> Wolves eat rabbits, rabbits eat grass, they have to go find it, if 
> they don't, they die, etc. As I said, I'm very new to this so any 
> advice or referrals would be great. I'm here to learn as much as I 
> can without being a burden. Thanks.
> 
> Timmy
> 
> p.s. also please tell me if i'm way over my head with this site. 
> thanks
